Rosewood Mayakoba: Complete Resort Guide

Where Jungle Meets Lagoon in Ultra-Luxury

Last updated: January 2025

Rosewood Mayakoba redefined what a Caribbean resort could be. Rather than clearing jungle for ocean views, they built within it—creating a labyrinth of lagoons, mangroves, and private suites accessible by boat. The result is a property where howler monkeys are your morning alarm, exotic birds fill the canopy, and your private plunge pool overlooks primordial waterways. This isn't a beach resort with nature nearby; it's a nature reserve that happens to have a beach.

In This Guide

  • Overview & Vibe
  • Accommodations
  • Dining
  • Sense Spa
  • El Camaleón Golf
  • Beach & Nature
  • Activities & Experiences

  • Booking Tips

Overview & Vibe

{<strong>The Mayakoba Concept:</strong></p><p>Rosewood Mayakoba exists within Mayakoba, a 1,600-acre master-planned resort community that also includes Fairmont, Banyan Tree, and Andaz properties. But Rosewood is the jewel—the most exclusive, most private, and most integrated with nature.</p><p><strong>Key Stats:</strong></p><ul><li>129 suites (all with private pools)</p><ul><li>1,600-acre Mayakoba development</p><ul><li>620 acres of protected mangroves</p><ul><li>El Camaleón golf course (PGA Tour venue)</p><ul><li>Opened 2008</p><ul><li>Staff-to-guest ratio: approximately 4:1</p><p><strong>The Vibe:</strong></p><ul><li>Nature immersion with ultra-luxury</p><ul><li>Architectural integration with environment</p><ul><li>Bohemian elegance</p><ul><li>Design-forward without being cold</p><ul><li>Active but unhurried</p><p><strong>Who Stays Here:</strong></p><ul><li>Design and architecture enthusiasts</p><ul><li>Nature lovers with luxury expectations</p><ul><li>Honeymooners seeking privacy</p><ul><li>Golf travelers (PGA Tour quality)</p><ul><li>Families wanting space and nature</p><ul><li>Wellness seekers}

Accommodations

{<strong>Suite Categories:</strong></p><p><strong>Lagoon Suites (from $2,500/night)</strong></p><ul><li>1,938 sq ft with private plunge pool</p><ul><li>Floor-to-ceiling windows on lagoon</p><ul><li>Outdoor rain shower and tub</p><ul><li>Private boat dock</p><ul><li>Butler service</p><p><strong>Overwater Suites ($3,500-4,500)</strong></p><ul><li>Built over the lagoon on stilts</p><ul><li>Glass floor panels to view marine life</p><ul><li>Private infinity pool</p><ul><li>Direct lagoon access for swimming</p><ul><li>Most requested category</p><p><strong>Beachfront Suites ($4,000-5,500)</strong></p><ul><li>Steps from Caribbean beach</p><ul><li>Larger private pools</p><ul><li>Indoor/outdoor living spaces</p><ul><li>Morning sunrise views</p><p><strong>Two-Bedroom Suites ($6,000-8,000)</strong></p><ul><li>3,400+ sq ft</p><ul><li>Ideal for families</p><ul><li>Multiple bathrooms</p><ul><li>Larger pool and outdoor space</p><p><strong>Deluxe Beachfront House ($10,000-15,000)</strong></p><ul><li>6,000+ sq ft standalone home</p><ul><li>3 bedrooms, private pool</p><ul><li>Full kitchen</p><ul><li>Dedicated staff</p><p><strong>Casa Laguna ($25,000-40,000)</strong></p><ul><li>5-bedroom private villa</p><ul><li>Over 10,000 sq ft</p><ul><li>Staff of 6 dedicated</p><ul><li>Ultimate buyout option</p><p><strong>Every Suite Includes:</strong></p><ul><li>Private plunge pool (heated)</p><ul><li>Butler service</p><ul><li>Twice-daily housekeeping</p><ul><li>Private boat transportation option</p><ul><li>Rosewood amenities</p><ul><li>Nespresso and tea service}

Dining

{<strong>Restaurants:</strong></p><p><strong>La Ceiba</strong> The signature restaurant in a stunning treehouse-like structure. Contemporary Mexican with Mayan influences. Chef sources from local farms and the resort's own garden.</p><ul><li>Dinner nightly</p><ul><li>Reservations essential</p><ul><li>$150-250 per person</p><ul><li>Dress: Resort elegant</p><p><strong>Casa del Lago</strong> Overwater restaurant for all-day dining. Mexican and international breakfast, seafood-focused lunch and dinner. The setting is magical—dining literally over the lagoon.</p><ul><li>Breakfast, lunch, dinner</p><ul><li>No reservations needed</p><ul><li>$60-120 per person</p><p><strong>Punta Bonita</strong> Beachfront casual dining with toes in sand. Ceviches, tacos, grilled seafood. Perfect for lunch after swimming.</p><ul><li>Lunch daily, dinner in high season</p><ul><li>Casual</p><ul><li>$40-80 per person</p><p><strong>Agave Azul</strong> Poolside bar and light bites. Excellent guacamole, tacos, and the resort's best margaritas.</p><ul><li>Lunch service</p><ul><li>Very casual</p><ul><li>$30-60 per person</p><p><strong>Aqui Me Quedo</strong> The swim-up bar and gathering spot. Snacks, drinks, and social atmosphere.</p><p><strong>In-Suite Dining:</strong></p><ul><li>Full menus available 24 hours</p><ul><li>Private chef experiences</p><ul><li>Romantic setups on your terrace</p><ul><li>Breakfast in your pool is popular}

Sense Spa

{<strong>Mayan-Inspired Wellness:</strong></p><p>Sense Spa at Rosewood Mayakoba draws on ancient Mayan healing traditions combined with contemporary techniques. The 17,000 sq ft facility is set among the mangroves, creating a journey just to arrive.</p><p><strong>Facilities:</strong></p><ul><li>14 treatment rooms (including couples)</p><ul><li>Outdoor treatment palapas</p><ul><li>Cenote-inspired plunge pools</p><ul><li>Temazcal (Mayan sweat lodge)</p><ul><li>Hydrotherapy circuit</p><ul><li>Beauty salon</p><ul><li>Fitness center</p><ul><li>Yoga pavilion</p><p><strong>Signature Treatments:</strong></p><p><strong>Temazcal Ceremony (2.5 hours, $600)</strong> Traditional Mayan sweat lodge led by a shaman. Deeply spiritual, physically intense. Transformative.</p><p><strong>Mayan Clay Renewal (90 min, $400)</strong> Local clay body wrap with jungle botanicals and massage.</p><p><strong>Sense Journey (3 hours, $800)</strong> Hydrotherapy, body treatment, and massage progression.</p><p><strong>Couple's Lagoon Suite (2 hours, $700)</strong> Private suite over the water with dual treatments.</p><p><strong>Wellness Programs:</strong></p><ul><li>Multi-day retreats available</p><ul><li>Private yoga and meditation</p><ul><li>Mayan healing consultations</p><ul><li>Nutritional guidance</p><ul><li>Sound healing sessions}

El Camaleón Golf

{<strong>PGA Tour Venue:</strong></p><p>El Camaleón Golf Club at Mayakoba is the only PGA Tour venue in Mexico. The course hosts the World Wide Technology Championship annually, bringing the world's best players.</p><p><strong>Course Details:</strong></p><ul><li>Designer: Greg Norman</p><ul><li>Par 72, 7,039 yards</p><ul><li>Unique ecosystems: jungle, mangroves, ocean, cenotes</p><ul><li>Playable hole through underground cenote</p><ul><li>Caribbean Sea views</p><p><strong>The Experience:</strong></p><ul><li>Holes weave through jungle, mangrove, and beach</p><ul><li>Wildlife encounters common (crocodiles in water hazards—really)</p><ul><li>Forecaddie program recommended</p><ul><li>Immaculate conditioning year-round</p><p><strong>Green Fees (Resort Guests):</strong></p><ul><li>18 holes: $350-425</p><ul><li>Twilight: $225</p><ul><li>Club rental: $95</p><ul><li>Forecaddie: $40 + tip</p><p><strong>Why It's Special:</strong></p><ul><li>Only PGA Tour course in Mexico</p><ul><li>Environmental integration unmatched</p><ul><li>Never overcrowded</p><ul><li>Same course the pros play</p><ul><li>Excellent practice facility}

Beach & Nature

{<strong>The Caribbean Beach:</strong></p><p>Rosewood has approximately 1 mile of Caribbean beachfront within Mayakoba. The beach is beautiful but seaweed can be an issue seasonally (resort works hard to maintain it).</p><p><strong>Beach Amenities:</strong></p><ul><li>Loungers and umbrellas</p><ul><li>Palapa shade structures</p><ul><li>Full food and beverage service</p><ul><li>Beach butlers</p><ul><li>Water sports center</p><ul><li>Towels, sunscreen provided</p><p><strong>Lagoon & Nature:</strong></p><p>The lagoon system is what makes Rosewood unique:</p><ul><li>Boat transportation throughout property</p><ul><li>Kayaking and paddle boarding</p><ul><li>Guided nature tours</p><ul><li>Crocodile spotting (from safe distance)</p><ul><li>Bird watching (180+ species)</p><ul><li>Howler monkey sightings daily</p><p><strong>Pools:</strong></p><ul><li>Main infinity pool (family-friendly)</p><ul><li>Adults-only pool</p><ul><li>Every suite has private pool</p><p><strong>Eco-Initiatives:</strong></p><ul><li>Protected mangrove habitat</p><ul><li>Sea turtle conservation</p><ul><li>Native plant restoration</p><ul><li>No single-use plastics</p><ul><li>Sustainable seafood sourcing}

Activities & Experiences

{<strong>Complimentary Activities:</strong></p><ul><li>Guided nature walks</p><ul><li>Kayaking and paddle boarding</p><ul><li>Snorkeling equipment</p><ul><li>Fitness classes</p><ul><li>Bicycle use throughout property</p><ul><li>Kids' activities (seasonal)</p><p><strong>Premium Experiences:</strong></p><p><strong>Cenote Excursion ($200/person)</strong> Private guided trip to nearby cenotes. Swimming, snorkeling, and Mayan history.</p><p><strong>Cooking Class ($250)</strong> Mexican cuisine with resort chefs. Market tour optional.</p><p><strong>Private Lagoon Dinner ($1,500+)</strong> Boat to a private dock, candlelit dinner in the mangroves.</p><p><strong>Sunrise Boat Tour ($150)</strong> Early morning wildlife observation. Birds, crocodiles, quiet magic.</p><p><strong>Mayan Ruins Tour ($300)</strong> Private guided visit to Tulum or Cobá.</p><p><strong>For Families:</strong></p><ul><li>Rose Buds program (ages 5-12)</p><ul><li>Family kayak adventures</p><ul><li>Junior golf program</p><ul><li>Movie nights under the stars</p><ul><li>Wildlife education programs</p><p><strong>For Couples:</strong></p><ul><li>Private temazcal</p><ul><li>Romantic boat dinners</p><ul><li>Couple's spa journey</p><ul><li>Starlight cinema</p><ul><li>Private beach picnics}

Practical Information

{<strong>Getting There:</strong></p><ul><li>Cancún Airport (CUN): 45-55 minutes</p><ul><li>Private transfer: $180 each way (sedan), $250 (SUV)</p><ul><li>Helicopter transfers available</p><ul><li>Resort is gated within Mayakoba</p><p><strong>Location Within Mayakoba:</strong></p><ul><li>Closest to beach of the four hotels</p><ul><li>Guests can visit Banyan Tree, Fairmont restaurants</p><ul><li>El Camaleón course shared with all properties</p><p><strong>Best Time to Visit:</strong></p><ul><li>Peak season: December-April (dry, less humidity)</p><ul><li>Whale shark season: June-September</p><ul><li>Lowest rates: September-November</p><ul><li>Seaweed: Unpredictable, often March-August</p><p><strong>What to Pack:</strong></p><ul><li>Insect repellent (jungle environment)</p><ul><li>Long pants for evening (mosquitoes)</p><ul><li>Light layers for AC</p><ul><li>Golf attire if playing</p><ul><li>Reef-safe sunscreen</p><p><strong>Dress Codes:</strong></p><ul><li>La Ceiba: Resort elegant</p><ul><li>Other restaurants: Smart casual to casual</p><ul><li>No swimwear in restaurants</p><p><strong>Connectivity:</strong></p><ul><li>WiFi throughout property</p><ul><li>Cell service good</p><ul><li>Some suites have spotty service (jungle)}

Pros & Cons

{<strong>Why Choose Rosewood Mayakoba:</strong></p><p>✅ <strong>Pros:</strong></p><ul><li>Truly unique lagoon/mangrove setting</p><ul><li>Every suite has private pool</p><ul><li>Exceptional spa with Mayan traditions</p><ul><li>PGA Tour golf on property</p><ul><li>Wildlife immersion (howler monkeys, birds, crocs)</p><ul><li>Design-forward architecture</p><ul><li>Butler service all categories</p><ul><li>Nature-focused without sacrificing luxury</p><ul><li>Boat transportation is magical</p><p>❌ <strong>Cons:</strong></p><ul><li>Very expensive ($2,500+ minimum)</p><ul><li>Seaweed can affect beach seasonally</p><ul><li>Insects require attention (jungle reality)</p><ul><li>45+ minutes from Cancún airport</p><ul><li>Not all-inclusive (add $400-600/day for food)</p><ul><li>Humid environment (part of jungle experience)</p><ul><li>Limited nightlife (nearest is Playa del Carmen)</p><ul><li>Some guests want more beach, less lagoon</p><p><strong>Compared to Alternatives:</strong></p><ul><li>vs. One&Only Palmilla: Rosewood for nature/design, Palmilla for beach/golf</p><ul><li>vs. Chablé: Rosewood for beach access, Chablé for inland retreat</p><ul><li>vs. Grand Velas: Rosewood for exclusivity, Grand Velas for all-inclusive</p><ul><li>vs. Banyan Tree (same complex): Rosewood more refined, Banyan Tree more intimate}

Booking Tips

{<strong>How to Book:</strong></p><p><strong>Best Approach:</strong></p><ol><li>Virtuoso or Amex Fine Hotels & Resorts advisor</p><ol><li>Advisor benefits: Upgrade, credit, breakfast, early/late</p><ol><li>Book 3-5 months ahead for winter</p><ol><li>Summer offers significant discounts</p><p><strong>Suite Selection Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Overwater Suites book first—reserve early</p><ul><li>Lagoon Suites excellent value (still have pools)</p><ul><li>Beachfront for those prioritizing beach over lagoon</p><ul><li>Request high-numbered suites for privacy</p><p><strong>Money-Saving Strategies:</strong></p><ul><li>September-October: 30-40% lower rates</p><ul><li>May-June: Good rates, before peak summer</p><ul><li>Ask about 4th or 5th night free</p><ul><li>Book refundable, watch for promotions</p><p><strong>What to Request:</strong></p><ul><li>Suite away from boat traffic (if sensitive to noise)</p><ul><li>Near beach or near spa (depending on priorities)</p><ul><li>Dietary accommodations (excellent at handling)</p><ul><li>Golf tee times pre-arrival</p><ul><li>Spa bookings pre-arrival (high season)</p><p><strong>Mayakoba Considerations:</strong></p><ul><li>Can dine at other Mayakoba properties</p><ul><li>Golf shared with Banyan Tree, Fairmont, Andaz</p><ul><li>Rosewood beach is best in complex}

Frequently Asked Questions

Is the seaweed situation at Rosewood Mayakoba bad?

It varies by season and year. The resort employs a full-time beach maintenance team, but during peak sargassum season (often March-August), the beach can be affected. The lagoon, pools, and cenote excursions are unaffected. Check recent reviews for current conditions before booking.

Are the mosquitoes and insects really a problem?

It's a jungle—insects are part of the ecosystem. The resort manages them well, and most guests adjust quickly. Bring repellent, wear long pants at evening, and you'll be fine. The tradeoff is howler monkeys, exotic birds, and a setting unlike any other resort.

How does boat transportation work?

Boats operate continuously throughout the day and evening. Call from your suite and one arrives within 5-10 minutes. It's a magical way to travel the property, watching wildlife en route. Walking paths exist too if you prefer.

Is Rosewood Mayakoba good for families?

Excellent for families who appreciate nature and can afford it. The two-bedroom suites work well, kids love the wildlife and boat rides, and the Rose Buds program is solid. It's not a kids' activity resort though—don't expect water slides.

Should I choose Rosewood or stay at another Mayakoba property?

Rosewood is the most refined and nature-integrated option. Banyan Tree is more intimate with outstanding villas. Fairmont is family-focused with more amenities. Andaz is newest and most design-forward. All share golf and can cross-dine. Rosewood guests generally don't feel the need to explore other properties.
